Confessions of an Unrepentant Alumnus, or How I Tried to Get My Degree Revoked Through Blogging    I just found my diploma while sifting through some random boxes of personal papers in my closet. Itâs framed in a Wal-Mart plastic frame, because I didnât really want to invest in the solid brass medallion and gold leaf trim and stupid amounts of money they ask for such things. Itâs sort of strange and terrible that they nickel and dime you on the way out of collegeâ¦ graduation gown this, yearbook that, âmemories that will last forever,â et cetera.   The truth is, I didnât even walk for graduation. My parents were disappointed what with my being the first member of my family to be granted a bachelorâs degree from an accredited institution, but hereâs how I tricked them; my sister (who is much better at school than I am) was accepting an award for academic superiority at Jorgensen auditorium, and there was a keynote speaker. And he droned on about how great sports were, and other school spirity things. I leaned over to my mom and dad, and whispered in a really loud whisper voice, âThis is what graduation is going to be like, only MORE boring.â And thus, I was able to watch cartoons in my underpants while my fellow students stood up in unison, and wore all black, tossing their mortarboards into the sky of an uncertain future.  Why didnât I walk? There are a lot of reasons, but I think the biggest one was I didnât really want to be a part of the pomp and circumstance capstoning a four year odyssey of terrible bullshit. This is not to say I learned nothing in college; I got a fairly good grip on delivery phone numbers, and I figured out how long it took to get to my classes from my dorm, so to optimize sleeping. I learned how to fake a mean F chord. And, you know, whateverâ¦ some good âdealing with peopleâ skills or something, although I think my summer job at a Scout camp really sharpened those and made me the witty bastard I am today.   Now, Iâm not one of the illiterati. I love learning. There were some times in college, while in the depths of some lengthy paper Iâd put off until about 12 hours before it was due, where I remembered exactly how much I loved learning. Itâs a shame it didnât happen more oftenâ¦ and this is part of the reason why I think higher education is so fucked up. How can an institute âdedicatedâ to the enlightenment and enrichment of young minds be such a hotbed of apathy and destructive behavior?  College is populated by a pretty substantial demographic of kids who donât really want to be there. Well, they DO want to be there, for the keggers and promiscuity. It tends to be worse at pricier, private colleges, where itâs a bunch of rich kids waving their gold plated dicks around. Iâve seen it. And itâs disgusting. Bunch of lazy, shiftless, empty people waiting to be kicked out for hitting the bong six too many times a day.  Not that good students are any better. Fuck those squares, says I! I would have studied harder if I wasnât afraid of becoming one of them. I mean, think about itâ¦ whatâs worse than lazy people in college? Study dorks! Locking themselves in their rooms, avoiding the light of day, looking down their noses at people sunning themselves in the quad and playing wiffle ball. I mean, at least the lazy folks try to make the best out of a bad thing. Study, study, study, get a diploma, get a good jobâ¦ do more work. These people are setting themselves up for juicy heart attacks.   The Studious make me even sadder for our future than the shiftless and unambitious. Hereâs whyâ¦ think about studying for a test. What do you do? Cram as much knowledge into your head as possible, and take the test, and do well on it. And you promptly forget everything you learn. I defy any college student to tell me what they learned about three semesters ago. This excludes fundamentals coursesâ¦ but even those are forgotten, especially the stuff you donât use in your advanced classes. And as for college graduates, everything fades once you embark into the dim, hazy world of corporate America. Even if you use your degree in your job, you still donât remember all those elective classes that were supposed to round you out as a person. Voyage of the beagle wha? History of South Africa who? Introduction to archaeology huh?    The sad truth is, colleges make it okay to practice academic bulimia, binging on sweet fatty knowledge and puking it up on a blue book or bubble sheet, only to make room for economics or art history. They encourage this mediocrity, stuffing syllabi so full of crap that no one could know the breadth of it without a frenzied bout of studying for weeks before midterms. But wait, letâs make all the tests occur within a week and a half of each other, to make people study even more frantically, and lose even more of it! Now, there is cursory analysis in some of the tests, but nothing really profound, and nothing original. Compare and contrast the work of Cicero and Virgil with special consideration for the concept of character assassination. And blah blah blah. These âanalyticalâ essays are basically arguments the professor made in class, so you are in fact just regurgitating more crap. Dance, student DANCE! Dance around like a little puppet and bend over like a bitch! If you canât binge orally, weâll have to administer your education anally.   And we PAY for this!  So this academic Ebola perpetuates itself, festering in the fabled âtest libraries of fraternitiesâ and 3x5s full of stat formulae. We lose the cards, we pass or fail tests, we go through the motions. And everyoneâs ok with it. As long as the letter you get at the end of a semester is nearer the beginning of the alphabet, game on! Itâs ALL about the bottom line. And for those of you studious folks who say âgo fuck yourself, Scott, I learn plenty and I love what Iâm learning and itâs not just about the gradeâ¦â well, I dare you to audit a semester worth of courses and receive no grade for them whatsoever. You wonât do it. Because the grade is too damn importantâ¦ grade point averages! Oh, no, I need a good GPA! If I donât Iâll become a homeless person!! People kill themselves just to get a high number on their transcripts. I remember another set of numbers that were terribly important to everyone a few years backâ¦ SAT scores. Havenât thought about THOSE in a while, have you? Itâs the same with these letters and numbers. Your percentile isnât worth a damn once youâre above and beyond this strange transitory period. After your first couple jobs, no one will even care. There will be new numbers to fret about. Now, children, repeat after meâ¦ Quotasâ¦ Quarterly Reviewsâ¦ four oh one Kays.  I remember my dad once said to me, âCollege proves to employers that youâre trainable.â And I said to myself, thatâs cool thenâ¦ this was when I was much younger. So I expected to learn how to learn, you know? But thatâs the opposite of what happens. What I learned was if you give the professor what he or she wants, you will pass the class. Itâs just a matter of figuring out what they want and giving it to them. So the content is not as important as the delivery of said content. So every semester, you had to start from scratch, unless you already had the prof, and then you just did well from the get go. Thatâs the secret to getting good gradesâ¦ you donât have to learn anything, you simply need to feign competence.   But why does this happen? Why would we pay so much money to these institutions, entrusting them with our education? Because the colleges feign competence as well. Job placement statistics, percentages of valedictorians attending classes, et cetera. They give us and our parents what we want to hear in our senior year of high school. âWe have a good program that will get you a good job.â And we believe them, and for the most part it works. People go on to lead productive lives and contribute positively to society, working just hard enough to get raises, marrying the college sweetheart, making 2.5 kiddies, which you will of course send to college. Itâs a perpetual motion machine that makes the world turn, fueled by emptiness and mediocrity.   Most of what I value as far as my education goes is what I taught myself, by reading books that were on no syllabus, save the one in my head. I read, I interpreted, I grew as a result. I never needed to prove this acquisition of knowledge to anyone but me. itâs a lifelong processâ¦ I continue to read things that change my mind, and I enjoy learning immensely, because the knowledge is acquired on my own terms. Iâve read many philosophy books, despite having escaped college without a single philosophy credit under my belt. I like to understand them without the bias of an âexpert,â who taints the material with his own agendas. Iâve read almost every holy book, and integrated teachings and morality from each into my own personal code of conduct. All this, having never benefited from a single theology course. These things, I think, are best leaned in the confines of oneâs own mind, sitting quietly with a cup of hot tea, without the stress of highlighting and writing in margins because of a âbig test.â I donât need tests to keep me honest about what I learn.  So after I looked at my bachelor of arts degree (lovingly laser printed and embossed with the seal of our great state), I put it back, shitty frame and all, into the box with the other things I donât need to validate my existence. I donât need a piece of paper to prove anything to anybody. The proof, as Temple grad Bill Cosby was rumored to have said, is in the pudding. So the next time you canât read a book because you are too busy with classes (I have heard this excuse, and I almost threw up with disgust), think about what youâre really being taught in the ivory tower, and why youâre eating the sweet lotuses that are making you content with forgetting things after youâve proven you know them. Youâre better off listening to meaningful songs and learning secret truths between the lines of wise dead folks and breakfast cereal jingles. When you are beholden to no one, there is no failureâ¦ only steps toward the truth.   Educate yourself; it is an infinitely more satisfying path.  -- The Slater

Friends   What is a friend? 1.	A person whom one knows, likes, and trusts.  2.	A person whom one knows; an acquaintance.   There are of course different types of friends.  There are those who we know, like, and trust.  There are also those who we simply know.  In order to have a discussion on the merits of friendship, or the lack merits, we must differentiate between the two.  We cannot expect tremendous compassion, and support from all of our friends.  There are many people with very large amounts of acquaintances.  We cannot expect our more casual friends to bend over backwards for us.  While I think that we all know this and do not expect this much we must first be clear that most of our friends will never fill any supportive role.  We should however be able to expect compassion and support from a select few.  For many there is only one person that ever fills this role.  Our best friends should be people that we can count on.  We should be able to call them no matter what time.  Donât however expect that if you call someone at 5 am they will be bright-eyed and bushy-tailed.  Also, calling someone at a ridiculous time of the night/day should be reserved for emergencies only.     âAfter High School [my friends] pretty much vanishedâ   First of all let me say that this happened to me as well.  The people I was close with in High School I am not close with at all now.  I do have friends from high school, but the people I spend time with now I did not then.  Or at least not as much time.  My closest friendships are those that developed during my late teens and early twenties.  As people go off to school, work, military, or whatever connections are lost.  People drift apart and itâs not usually just one sideâs fault.   Should friends be anything more than people you enjoy spending time with?â   My answer is no.  You are very right Mr. Green.  But, I must say that there can be more to a friendship.  Donât expect your friends to make you into anything.  I agree with you on that.  There are people out there who can be trusted, and counted on.  Itâs a two way street though.  If a relationship isnât developed on both sides then no one is really to blame.  Let me use myself as an example.  Not that many people know me too well.  Not really at least.  I donât let people in.  Therefore, most of the friends I have are not that close.  Thatâs ok, and itâs my fault.  They are people I enjoy spending time with.  I have a few people that I can open up to and really talk to and be comfortable with.  People that I trust.  Including you Mr. Green.  Just remember that there is no magic safety net.  No, one is perfect.  That doesnât mean, though, that putting trust in anyone but yourself is bound to get you hurt.  There is risk involved in any relationship in which you open yourself emotionally.  There are no guarantees in life.  Being unwilling to trust people though is no way to live.  Your friends are not liarsâ¦  You can trust me on this one - Iâm one of your friends.  Jeffrey "---" Motola

What are friends for?    Friend, how camest thou in hither? -- Matt. 22:12  America was first visited by Friends in 1656. -- T. Chase  Want gives to know the flatterer from the friend. -- Dryden     This may not be the best time to write this. Heh â I mean thereâs never really a right time for anything it seems butâ¦ well there are so many things I donât knowâ¦ a number of things I havenât gotten my hands on or been able to wrap my mind around. Unresolved conflicts, rushed resolutions, and flat out closed mindedness on my part are sure to lend more than a fair share of bias to this piece. I canât imagine, though, that Iâll ever be seated in the right place to get this down properly. In fact, now that I think about it, this may very well be the best time to write this.  Who am I kiddingâ¦  Regardless of the timing, Iâll get on with it. For now, this feels important. Not to mention the fact that ideas like this lend themselves to wordy essays and like responses.  (pauseâ¦ Continue)   Iâve never really had much trouble making friends. In elementary school, I was a bit of a weirdo being that I was one of 5.8 black kids in my school andâ¦ wellâ¦ I was an odd duck beside that. Kids gravitated towards me and I had friends no matter how strangely I behaved. By the time I was in high school, my friends spanned the forever-wide gap between lowly geek and mountain top jock. I fit everywhere. I was invited to parties because I could make people laugh. I could sit damn near anywhere in the lunch roomâ¦ even if I didnât know the people â hell in 5 min, I could make a friend out of almost anyone. I was almost always the first one to talk to the shy new kid. I was the guy that defended the nerds. I was the kid that stared down the meatheads and made them take back their band insults. I was the kid that showed that jocks have personality beyond their jersey numbers and school records.   Now I was by no means a hero or a perfect kid. In fact, I was a bit of an asshole. At the same time that Iâd stand up for anyone, lunch ladies included, Iâd just as easily tear them down. It really depended on my mood to be honest. There were only a few people (this included you, Josh) who meant much of anything to me in the long run. Iâm looking back now and realizing that most of my friends were social white noise. They helped me ignore how awkward and insecure I was. I didnât count on them for much of anything but to show up to school. And, like I said, there were a few who were worth a damn but, after high school, they pretty much vanished and I was left to start again from scratch.   In college, making friends was effortless and I wasted no time. I knew hundreds and hundreds of people after just a year there but, just as it was in high school, I didnât much feel that I could count on any of them for anything. But is that even important? By that I meanâ¦ should friends be anything more than people you enjoy spending time with?  Hoping on over to present day, I still have plenty of friends. And, let me be honest with you, theyâre some of the best friends a guy could ever hope for. And yet, somehow, Iâm still disappointed. I couldnât put my finger on it for a while and the past few months Iâve wrestled with it somewhat silently. I have all these friends and Iâm still lonely. Why? Then it hit me. Iâm expecting my friends to fill a space that they donât have toâ¦   Hear me outâ¦  I kept expecting some sort of magic safety netâ¦ if I ever fell, I was ok what with all the friends I have, right? Someone was bound to helpâ¦ or at least understand. But, though some tried to help, no one really understood. And Iâm terrible at explaining myselfâ¦ so I put a smile on and moved on when the shit hit the fan. And tactics like that are doomed to fall apart someday. My real problem, Iâm coming to realize, was that no one took much time to get to know me â and, for whatever reason, I sort of expected them to do so. Iâve always been a decent friend to people for the most part but rarely have I ever had a chance at the âclose friendâ role. So I foolishly go to these people expecting help or support or whatever it is Iâm looking for (most times I donât much know) and of course theyâre at a loss for what to say or do. Outside of the context of a party, hanging out, or the occasional late night conversation, there wasnât much. Now, thatâs not to say that there wasnât anythingâ¦ or even to say that there was only a little or that what was there was somehow insignificantâ¦  This is as good a time as any to get to the pointâ¦  What are friends for? All weâve heard via TV, radio, and such lead us to believe that friends are to be these wonderful pillars in our lives â âFriends give you wings to flyââ¦ and all that. But what if they arenât? What if friends are nothing more than people you enjoy spending time with? Now look, I understand that âfriendâ means different things to different people but I think itâs fair to say that weâve all looked to our friends for support at some point. My question is, what do you do when they wonât help?... or canât help? I mean you canât exactly get pissed at them. No one made any promises so none were broken. Whatâs more, the fact that, for whatever reason, theyâre unable to help you doesnât make them any less of a friend. Theyâre trying to get byâ¦ just like youâ¦ let go of your artificial expectations. As cold as that may sound, itâs true. Itâs a little ridiculous to be pissed or disappointed in someone who really hasnât made any type of commitment.  I know I knowâ¦ I have yet to answer my own questionâ¦ what are friends for? I donât much have anything in the way of a solid definition. I can say that friendship, as Iâve come to know it, means enjoying one anotherâs company for as long as it is mutually beneficial. Letâs be honestâ¦ thatâs all you can really hope for or count on. These dramatic definitions of friends saving lives and pulling one another out of the gutter are cheaper and more contrived than all the day time dramas combined. Weâve come to believe that our friends somehow owe us something because they associate with us. Whatâs more, we lie to one another as a means of indicating how important the other is with such clichÃ©s as âIf you ever need me, callâ¦ no matter what timeâ and âIâd do anything for youâ. Try calling on someone who has said this to you and see what kind of reception you get.   Obvious lies.  Why?  Real friends donât have to make promises or declarations. Such things are understood. Whatâs more, no real friend would expect another friend to take on the burden of their distresses. Thatâs just plain selfish. Your burdens are your own, chum. If you havenât learned that by now, you soon will. Those lofty pop-culture borne ideals of what a friend should be are flat out wrong. Friends are not our lifelines. Letâs be honest with one another here â we wouldnât trust the majority of our friends with our CDâsâ¦ to hell with our emotional wellbeing. Expect anything but good times and warm smiles and youâre in for some bitter disappointment.  I wasted a hell of a lot of time having high expectations of my âcloseâ friends. I made myself available to them at anytime â I mean I never said noâ¦ not because Iâm such a great guy but because it was the thing to do â itâs how I thought friendship worked. Likewise, I expected the same from them. When I did end up needing people, I looked around and saw that they kept on partying and working and living their lives while I sorted out my messes and confusions alone. I couldnât figure out how to say âHey! I need you!â and so I became even more depressed, confused and alone. No one really paid much attention and it bothered me a good deal until I finally said to myselfâ¦ why should they? Why should anyone help me with the messes Iâve gotten myself into? Hell, itâs  my  life, my problems, my responsibility. If friends decide to get involved, more power to them. If not, donât let yourself be catapulted into depression and confusion and whatnot. Get over it and deal with it yourself. Honestly.  Somehow weâve come to believe that we canât do it all on our own â that we need friends and loved ones to âcarry us throughââ¦ carry us through what? Are you serious? I guarantee this:  Putting trust in anyone but yourself is bound to get you hurt  and, if youâre particularly unlucky, itâll lose you some quality friends. Look, Iâm not saying I donât trust anyone â I certainly trust my mother and a good number of other people. I am saying that believing that you can truly count on anyone but yourself to help you out of hard times or into good ones is just plain foolish. People let you downâ¦ thatâs what they do. Iâll tell you right now, itâll be a long time before I trust anyone with more than a joke and a beer.   Dexter you old fart! This is bullshit! I completely trust my close friends with my life and Iâm sure they trust me with theirs. Theyâve helped me out of countless rough spots and I know that I can count on them whenever I need them.   How nice for you. Listenâ¦ all itâs gonna take is one timeâ¦ youâre in dire need and you look around and no one is their but you and your problems. What are you gonna do when there are no phone calls to make or IMâs to send thatâll solve everything? Short-armed bastards like you will end up a pile of snot and worry. Youâll choke down a few of mommyâs magic pills to help you sleep a good long forever sleepytime nap and your friends will forget about you before the earth above your head is firm. What makes me so sure?  Your friends are liarsâ¦ all of them  You can trust me on this one â Iâm not one of your friends.  They tell you what they think you want to hear. They tell you what they think will get you out of the funk youâre in. They really donât give much of a shit about anything but how you behave. As far as your actual well-being is concerned, they could care less. Why? Wellâ¦ thereâs really nothing than can do or even want to do about itâ¦ furthermore, they donât want to hear about problems that they canât immediately solve or give you a quick answer to â as long as youâre quiet about it, they wonât mention it either. And so long as they can get a good time out of you, theyâll take that as a sign that everything is ok and move right along.   Wake up â itâs true. And you thought you had âtrue friendsâ? â glad I had the privilege of disappointing you.   And, again, why should it be any different? Why should are friends be anything more than people who enjoy our company?     Youâll waste half of your life looking for friends âjust like on TV and in the movies!â only to find that such people do not exist. Weâre not alone in life, that much is true, but all the work is on our shoulders. The most you can hope for is a few lookers on.   What are friends for?  Hell, with all this babbling, I donât think Iâve answered that question exactly. And, to be honest, I donât yet claim to know what friends are forâ¦ or if there is actually an answer to that question. I do know what they are  not  for. (see above)  Donât expect your friends to make you into anything â a happier,  saner, more mature, fulfilled personâ¦. Any of that bullshit â thatâs all up to you entirely.   Itâs your life and you are on your own. Friends are better than video games...  Get your fucking weight up, chump.   ---  Dexter Otis Green

A Fireside Chat with Uncle Vicodin    Tripped and fell this afternoonâ¦ leg hurts like a bitch.  Iâve been fighting it for most of the day, and Iâve finally given in and popped a vicodin.  So letâs see how my writing degenerates as I slip into madness, eh?  So Iâm just going to be keeping a running tab of whatâs going on around me, self editing as little as possible, though I will admit to doing some just now.  I will also admit to listening to rentâ¦ 525600 minutesâ¦ dunno why itâs on my computer.  GOnna change it. Switching over to jesus Christ superstar.  Big fan.  I love how judas and Christ are portrayedâ¦ so deliciously blasphemous, or so the religious right would have you believe.  Kinda gives them both a human edgeâ¦ which makes sense.  Even the greatest heroes and storymakers among us are, at their cores, just people.  Talented, maybe.  But by and large, theyâre just like you and me, if we were put into an extraordinary situation.  I mean, howâd you react to being told youâre godâs son, sent to save the world by dying for it?  Okâ¦ I think Iâm gonna switch off of JCSS, cause itâs a little too religiousâ¦ just gonna listen to heaven on their minds and rock it back on the back burnere until such time as Iâm not about to lose motor skills and basic judgement. Badass guitar riffâ¦ ROCK! Powerful voice, crazy bidnessâ¦ I think Iâm gonna have a cigarette.  I like cigarettes. Judas is badass.  In the musical.  And the bible, I guessâ¦ I mean, if it werenât for judas growing some balls and selling jesus out, he wouldnât have been able to die on the cross, right?  So in a sense, judas had to do what he did.  Should he be punished for this?  Or if you take the âjudas possessed by satanâ stance, should satan be punished for indirectly enabling salvation?  Doesnât make a lot of sense.  	Ok, new section, to be started as JCSS is eliminatedâ¦ voted off the aural island, so to speak. For continuityâs sake, it should be stated that this was written before the heaven on their minds commentary.  Andâ¦. Action.  Kid A is playing nowâ¦ much better atmospheric music.  Everything in its right placeâ¦ I like it.  Am I starting to fragment yet?  I hope notâ¦ thereâs no discernable pain reliefâ¦ I burned my finger on a hot skillet the other  dayâ¦ wonder if thatâll stop hurting tooâ¦ I suppose it will.  Now, for no particular reason, Iâm staring at an executioner miniature given to me by my roommate.  Itâs from his trip to London.  He looks vaguely sinister, standing over miniature Frodo, sitting in my desk lamp/ organizer. I have a set of RPG dice and casino dice there too.  I have a weakness for purchasing dice.  Itâs not like Iâm a statistician, or anything.  Nor do I think all things are left to chance, or luck.  Nor do I believe that itâs destiny, either.  It seems like everything justâ¦ is.  In its right place, I suppose.  My damned speakers are buzzing because of the sick amount of bass being thrown off by Thom yorke and his cronies.  I have to turn down the volume.  Kind of makes everything quiet, and distant.  The Vicodin will likely intensify this feeling.  The tactile reality of the keys beneath my fingers is creating a not entirely unpleasant sensation.  Ah, delicious double negatives.  Theyâre fun, letting you be dramatic in speech and prose.  Even though theyâre redundant.  But writing is being redundant.  So why are they so often avoided in grade school comp classes?  If I were to write as succinctly as possible, it wouldnât be very interesting.  Of course, this article might not be very interesting either.  Fuck it.  Iâm plodding along.  Hit track three already.  I used to fall asleep to Kid A, but now I prefer this odd little mp3 track I picked up somewhere or another.  Itâs kind of droning background music, with whacky little pulses, supposedly stimulating REM sleep.  It does, for all I know.  I rarely remember my dreamsâ¦ theyâre gone as my eyes open.  Sometimes I mentally grasp at the grains of sand which are my dreams as they slip through my fingers, descending into the vast oblivion that lies directly beneath our waking lives.  Itâs a fine line, you know.  Between reality and oblivion.  Water is good.  Nice and coldâ¦ I enjoy the feeling of drinking an ice cold glass of water when youâre really thirsty and havenât had anything in your system for a whileâ¦ you feel the chill go down through your upper body.  A similar sensation is achieved when you drink a hot beverage on a cold day.  But you know that already donât you?  I donât know why Iâm chronicling itâ¦ it just seems like the thing to do.  This is as close to stream of consciousness as I get.  There are many more things slipping around in my head, but I canât type fast enough to get them all down.  I can barely keep up with what Iâm trying to focus on.  Iâm making it a little bit of a race, trying to write it down so quickly that I can catch up, but I donât think Iâll be able to. Ehâ¦ fuck it.  I guess Iâm writing crazy talk because everyone else seems to be.  You wonât know it while reading this, but there was a considerable dramatic pause right there.  It would be interesting to develop a way to â¦ looking for the word.  Just a momentâ¦ read in real time, at the same speed the author wrote it downâ¦ kind of like spoken word, but with writing.  In retrospect, this is a strange and terrible idea which sucks.  Scratch it.  I was briefly considering going back through what Iâve written down so far, but I decided against it, since it would bias the rest of the piece.  It now occurs to me that biasing the piece doesnât really matterâ¦ hypotheticals are bullshit.  But still, Iâm not going back, even though I could and it would be alright.  Maybe later on I will.  It might be entertaining.  I have a fantastic set of tapes which feature E.E. Cummings reading many of his poemsâ¦ itâs on four cassettes, and he goes through all of his really well known ones, as well as his more obscure onesâ¦ including ones Iâve never read.  It is a really fantastic collection because going back and reading the poems afterwards, you can see the flow the man had, even though his text is formatted like a crazy person using magnetic poetry.  It makes me look at his work in a completely different way.  Poems are good because reading them and hearing them offer two vastly different experiences.  Donât remember when I took the pill, but it should be a half hour after that point where my crazy will truly begin to set inâ¦ felt a chill across my brain, which might mean that itâs coming along.  So bear with me.  Just did a word countâ¦ upwards of 1200 words.  Definitely feeling changes.  Getting a little lightheaded.  Wish I had a laptop so I could sit in bed and type that way.  But alas, I must suffer.  Oh wellâ¦ my hands have developed many more scars over the past year or so than Iâd ever had on them before.  The burn from the skillet, which I talked about beforeâ¦ plus a couple where I whanged my hand pretty hard, and started to bleedâ¦ theyâre still discolored, even though I got them a while ago.  Wonder if theyâll ever fade into that sickly white associated with so many other scars.  I also have pit in my lip where a mother of a cold sore lived.  You love to hear about that, donât you?  Herpes herpes bo berpesâ¦ heh heh.  But that onesâ not going away.  I wonder what it would be like to have small poxâ¦. Just nasty scars all about your face.  I wonder how people dealt with thatâ¦ I mean, theyâre shit loads worse than acne scars.  And acne scars are pretty bad. Wiped a little sweat off of my browâ¦ cool to the touch.  Donât know how long Iâm going to be able to hold up with thisâ¦ urge to sleep risingâ¦ although the headache is going away.  Glad I donât have any alcohol in meâ¦ or Iâd be really whackeâ¦ oh, waitâ¦ I had a hot chocolate with peppermint schnapps in it.  Hrmâ¦ this might complicate matters.  Oh well. Gonna take a short break.  	Ok, back.  I wrote that before the break.  For continuityâs sake.  ï  wowâ¦ I just smileyedâ¦. Weird.  Emoticons and net lingo have really pervaded our vernacular, havenât they?  Ok â¦ water break. Ok, back. All this talk about emoticons made me check my buddy list to see whoâs about.  I compulsively check away messagesâ¦ just scroll down the whole list.   Do any of you remember when they used to add checking profiles to your typing block limit?  The little bar under send.  I hated that.  Sometimes I would get locked out of being able to type.  Itâs disturbing to be disallowed expression.  It seems very symbolic, but that might be the drugs talking.  And ladies and gentlemen, let me assure you, they are talking.  gonna lay down for a little bit.  Be right back.  Drew just woke me up with a phone callâ¦ I only picked out like an eighth of the words he was sayingâ¦. Confusing and unsettling.  Dunno. Radiohead has resetâ¦ For some reason, Iâm now remembering burning this to cd and giving it to my ex girlfriend.  I remember drawing a crude facsimile of the bear with the teeth.  Which is My buddy Icon, Iâm pretty sureâ¦ checkingâ¦ just a moment. Yup, it is.  My arm is numb.  Makes typing an interesting prospect.  Iâm typing much more slowly now, I might have just embarrassed myself thru IMâ¦ I guess I didnât.  Talking to heatherâ¦ one of my very good friends.  False alarm, I have officially embarrassed myselfâ¦ letting slip my nefarious plans to seduce her with booze.  Hopefully it will slide under the radar.  Iâve added a wink smiley to make it more innocent, although trying to spin a plan for seduction into innocent banter is a difficult proposition.  Sheâs not answeringâ¦ this could be a bad sign.  Ehâ¦ these things happen.  Iâm eyeing my cigarettes.  Also a bad sign, since I know I just had one.    Words start to look funny when you single them out and disassociate their meaning form their makeup.  If you repeat them in your head over and overâ¦ they also start to sound funny.  Like youâre talking crazy gibberish talk.  Which also might be true regardless. Third time around for radiohead.    Iâm hitting the return button more often nowâ¦ the worst of the dizziness is gone, and everything is kind of separating, like Iâm lifting offâ¦ and sort of floating above myself.  Itâs kind of a dangerous place to be, because I am not particularly self conscious at this point, and donât care for/ recognize consequences.  I like the way the shadows play ac5ross my bedspreadâ¦ very abstract and whacky.. I think Iâm going to lay down now.   --  Scott "The Slater" Slater

School was easy for the first half of the day. I was in class with no more than 5 kids at a time most of the time so that worked out fine. But I was still very uncomfortable being around all those white people. Then lunch came and I freaked. I had made zero friends that day which meant I either had to sit alone or sit with white people and try to make friends.    	I sat alone.    	I remember sitting with my left arm around my tray, eyeballing the cafeteria DARING anyone to sit near me. I was so lonely and, part of me really wanted someone to come over. But I wasnât going to let them make me white. So I did the easiest thing a black kid could do in that school. I looked intimidating.   	Months passed, seasons changed and I had made friends with the kids on my bus (also from Hartford) and a few kids in school. They treated me like a visitor but it was ok. I had a few friends and that was better than eating alone. I had a small group of friend to go on the swings with at recess. Life wasnât all that bad.   	âNigger!â   	what?...    	I looked up from a game of Speedball and my new friendâ¦ weâll call him Dick Spiffy - was pointing at me.   	He was pointing at  me ? Was I a nigger?   	    	I knew I was black and that black people were sometimes called niggers by white people. But it was an entirely different thing to actually be called âNiggerâ outright. I was, to say the least, a little confused. Then, it hit me. It hit me light a lightning bolt and I took off after him.   	I beat the crap out of him.   	In the principalâs office, I got nothing but sympathy. It didnât go on my file or anything like that. It was dropped and I went back to class. But something had changed in me that took years to fix.   	The question lingered. Nigger? ME!?! Am I a nigger? I didnât know if it was true. Until then, I never had to ask myself if it was  true â¦ and, if it was trueâ¦ if I was a niggerâ¦ what did that mean?   	Nigger was something they called slaves. It was worse than a bad wordâ¦ it was a curse. When Dick resurrected that word, it felt worse than anything I had ever felt. I couldnât say why then but I think I knew. Nigger meant âYou are nothing â you are not one of us â You will never be one of us â You are lessâ¦ lowâ¦ and worthy of contemptâ. It was the embodiment of the evils of slavery. In North America, from the 1500s to 1865, âNiggerâ connoted âblack slaveâ but also âMaroon (A fugitive Black slave in the West Indies in the 17th and 18th centuries).â From then on, âNiggerâ connoted âsecond-class citizenâ as well as âMaroonââ¦ visitorâ¦ outcast. 23 years later it meant the very same thing when Dick used it on meâ¦ âOutcast! â Unclean!â   	Not one of you reading this needs the history of the word to know what it means.   	We all know what it means. Thereâs a definition beyond my words that weâre all familiar with. Nigger = hate. Itâs all but impossible to know how fucked up of a word it is until that hate is directed at you.    	Then there came Wigger.   	Wowâ¦ Wigger? Are you fucking kidding me?  WIGGER?!    	For the slow ones, âWiggerâ is a clever combination of words â âWhiteâ and âNiggerâ.  Astonishing.  	Let me get this straightâ¦ a wigger is a âWhite Niggerâ? What does that mean, exactly? Some kid wears Fubu and listens to 50-cent and Biggie andâ¦ well now heâs a Niggerâ¦ but he canât be a  nigger  nigger because heâs whiteâ¦ so heâs a  white  niggerâ¦ a wiggerâ¦ hahahaha! _ thatâs cleverâ¦ thatâs funny!      Guinness AML:  You know why I hate wigger more than nigger?  Guinness AML:  Amercian blacks were given the word nigger and told "This means you're nothing"  Guinness AML:  they took it and, over time, changed it to mean "This means we're family" - it's an identifier... a sacred word  Guinness AML:  which is why I can call a black person a nigger and you can't  wongdongy:  wow  Guinness AML:  Wigger is thievery  wongdongy:  haha  Guinness AML:  we were given shit and made it an heirloom  Guinness AML:  and now it's being taken back?!  Guinness AML:  FUCK that   	Yes â it is  our  word. Your grandfathers gave it to us, remember? They made sure we knew that it belonged to us and only us.   	And it does.   	Wigger isnât an outright attempt at reclaiming the word butâ¦ well once black folk made nigger cool, wigger pops upâ¦.this fucking generic bullshit word that manages to be more insulting than the first. How? By downplaying the significance of the word âniggerââ¦ Chinese dude âactinâ blackâ yo? Heâs a chigga, B.   	Nigger doesnât mean black. Nigger IS black. Itâs a black word. Humanity: the Toolmakers, or just Tools? (or: on being 24 and some monthsâ¦)    Iâm 24 and loving it.  I get to sleep late, be bothered by friends and family that I donât have a job (Iâm looking, kidsâ¦ trust me, Iâm looking.), watch cartoons in my underpants, and write my thoughts for the whole web to see.  Iâm trying my best not to be depressed about getting older, because Iâm really not that old.  Although, for all our crazy amounts of advancement, it seems that our developmental stage is increasing a great deal.  When my parents were my age, theyâd been married for three years.  And when their parents were my age, THEYâD been married for more like five or six.    This is not to say that Marriage is the âgateway to adulthood,â but itâs a serviceable litmus for judging how responsible and in the real world a person is.  In the age of my grandparents, a high school education could feed a family.  For my parents, a bachelorâs degree most certainly sufficed.  Now, all my friends are taking Grad school courses, getting more and more advanced degrees, and hiding in the ivory tower well into their middle 20s.  Pretty soon Doctorates will be run of the mill, and people wonât be beginning their intended careers until theyâre into their 30s.    	Is this a result of a longer life expectancy?  People are alive and kicking and active well into their 80s nowadays.  My Grandmother is full of pizzazz, and even remarrying (and donât think for a minute Iâm not a bit disturbed that sweet little gramma is getting more action than me nowadays).  Because life is longer, childhood follows suit.  Bunches of my friends still live with mom and dad (not that thereâs anything wrong with that, wink wink).  It seems acceptable to return to the nest to save up some cash and plan the next step.  Maybe this âgoing homeâ tendency is the reason for the prolonging of childhood.  And parents are of course not averse to this, because theyâre watching their kids grow up faster than an eldritch DJ spins up âCatâs in the Cradleâ at the social club mixer.  Maybe this is a good thingâ¦ maybe itâs keeping us young at heart.  But it remains a fact that folk are less willing to take on the responsibility that their folks and grandfolks took up at a much younger age.     	Thereâs another angle to this phenomenonâ¦ and itâs the reason I started this article.  I was sort of typing and filling space until I found the connection, and then BAM!  There it is.  Weâre living longer, and also staying younger longer BECAUSE our forefathers had done things to promote a newer, shinier reality.  We are growing older more slowly because we have the benefit of their mistakes.    We have a history.   Iâve seen 2001: a space odyssey many times, and I love the whole movie, but one of the most interesting parts is in the beginning, with all the crazy monkeys.  Theyâre monkeying around, drinking water and being generally simian, when the monolith descends and sort of speeds up their evolution.  And the one monkey (I think his name was moonwatcher in the book, but donât quote me)  is playing with the predatorâs bone one hot desert day and comes to the realization that he can use it to bonk other creatures on the head.    A lot of people think (and I donât necessarily disagree) that Monkeyface realizes he can use things as tools, and this is what makes him powerful enough to overcome the jaguar and the enemy tribe of monkeys, and eventually overcome the barriers of the earth itself.  We humans are hailed as the great toolmakers; we possess gadgets and objects of infinite intricacy and usefulness.  And we have the opposable thumbs to use them.  I love using them, myself, Iâm looking at my shiny (though not much more useful than a piece of paper) Palmtop Computerâ¦ a cigarette lighter (fire is officially our bitchâ¦ take that, animal kingdom!)  plastic bottles, even the computer Iâm using now.    But I think the fact that we are toolmakers is only a part of the equation.  All sorts of animals use tools.  Chimps use sticks to root out anthills, scratch their backs, et cetera.  Even without the opposable thumb we wave in front of them derisively, they still can make use of things not of their bodies.    So is it communication?  We have a wonderful language that allows us to convey things, like telling a fellow that a potted plant is about to fall on their head, or that you would like a hot dog with Cappyâs sauce upon it.    But thatâs not it eitherâ¦ animals communicate too, at least on some level.   Birdâs mating callsâ¦ gorilla gestures, screeching warnings.  And perhaps more useful than even our language is the hive mind, allowing flocks of birds to intuitively move as one while migrating, silently striding packs of wolves hunting, ants almost instantly knowing where food isâ¦ the ability to work as a unit makes for a great deal of efficiency (At the cost of individuality, which is why cellphones and Instant Messenger scare me, but thatâs another post altogether)  Neither toolmaking nor communication is manâs secret weapon, and although weâre damn good at it, weâre not the only game in town.  Youâd think that animals, communicating and using tools for so many eons, would eventually get better at it, but they donât.    Besides, tools and communication fail.  Weâre at the mercy of our dayplanners.  Things that should be making us more time in fact give us less free time.  Hunters and gatherers had all day to look around and dream, once the berries and carcasses were all in the nomadic village.  It is this dreaming that really started the whole thing.  Tools seem almost counterintuitive; are we using the tools, or are the tools using us?  Communication, for all its flowery eloquence, also fails us.  Thereâs no real way of being sure that what we convey is that which is understood by those who receive.  Feelings might be universal, but for all we know, all perception is unique.  You and I do not feel the same anger, the same love, the same sadness, we donât see the same car, the same hot blonde, the same color red.  For all of our wonderful words and objects, we remain, by and large, island universes.  We have nothing except a collectively shared, yet individually experienced, past.  History is what the beasts do not have.  They have instinct (which is badass, but thereâs not much choice in it) but itâs way too slow.  An animal will be killed at the hands of men for generations upon generations before they get it into their heads that the bipeds are not to be trusted.  The life, and experience of an animal ends with that animal.  It passes on its genes, makes a baby wolf, and the instinct and the cycle continue.  Wolves canât sit around the forest grove, fondly remembering Grandpa One Eye, reminiscing about how he once outsmarted the bobcat that one time, and wasnât it funny as hell?    The scene in 2001 is less about a single monkey learning how to use a bone as a weapon, and more about that monkey coming to the realization that his actions, and the actions of his brothers, can have a lasting effect on the world.    History is communication to the nth degree.  Our past is what allows us to grow older and stand on the shoulders of our ancestors and make improvements on their innovations.  It allows us to observe both personal and collective progress within our lifetimes.  It gives us a bar which is silently begging to be jumped over and raised.  Our communications and our tools are only symptoms of our understanding of what has come before.  Our past has given us a future.  But when you really get down to it, our history is flawed.  Itâs written by the victors, so sayeth Napoleon, and many stories and innovations are lost.  Misinformation and propaganda paint unreal pictures of the way things are.  Violent crime in this country decreases, and yet the mediaâs reporting of violent crime increases exponentially.  The powers that be understand the power of history, and use it to control reality.  We begin to see that what weâre taught about our past isnât a really accurate picture.  The present becomes the past all too quickly these days.  Americans have short memoriesâ¦ I can remember the vigils held on October 11th, 2001, the vows to never forget the attack upon our nation.  I remember the moment of silence on the radio on September 11th, 2002.  But this past year?  I donât remember a single thing, save some idle chatter on msnbc.  Itâs being pulled out again for the sake of election campaigns, but it will once again fade into obscurity, adorning the pages of history books as a footnote for the beginning of the 21st century.    History is our salvation, our opiate, and ultimately, our crutch and our untimely demise.  More and more information is out there these days, thanks to the internetâ¦ but the net is in a state of constant flux.  Websites change, but there is no record of what came before it.  Itâs going too fast.  Instinct has the benefit and disadvantage of being slow, it seems.  It takes its time and makes DAMN sure that the information is good and correct.  It does so at the cost of individual members in the species.  If our information age were to fail, what then?  Tribes of barbarians, sweeping through the streets of cities, destroying history. It would be the fall of Rome, all over again.  The Dark ages.  A time to gather together in the hollow shells of our technology, and try to piece together what we lost. We donât have the benefit of a rich oral tradition, save a collective memorization of the Adam Sandler âHanukkah Songâ.  We couldnât teach our children much more than survival.  If a dark age were to come upon us right now, our wonderful and terrible tools would rust, unused, unknown.  150 years from now, buckskin clad great grandchildren would be drying hides on the interstates, smashing open skulls with back massagers. Needless to say, it would be a considerable setback.  So I was wrongâ¦ history isnât the answer.  Now, bear with me.  Perhaps at the moment of cogitation, a new kind of organism was born: the Idea. Itâs a simpler sort of historyâ¦ and maybe history itself is an idea.  But think about how ideas work.  Passed from person to person, constantly mutating, spreading, dying out.  It sounds almost like a virus.  Maybe it isâ¦ a sort of electrical impulse virus soaring through words and feelings. Perhaps instinct is the evolutionary forefather of the idea, passed genetically, slowly...   Sprouting forth from instinct, Our brains were fertile grounds for the Ideas.  The mental capacity grew, and so grew innovation.  Designated as the vessels of ideas, we watch some of them grow, while some die on the vine.  Like the Gods we thought they were, Ideas have only to be forgotten to be killed. Stronger ideas seem to spread like wildfire, and sometimes two ideas that contradict have themselves a little conflict.  Holy wars, Inquisitions, Crusades.  And all the rest.  So are we at the whim of our ideologies?  Is it like some Douglas Adams novel, where lab mice are in control, and we are made to believe the opposite?  Are we the warships and Bentleys of a bunch of neurological impulses?  Are we just material side effects?  The fleshy housing of the abstract?  This seems to be a dismal way of looking at ourselves.  I like to think we ARE our abstractions, and we're sometimes caught up in the tangibility of it all.  Reality, expression, all of it is just a set of corporeal training wheels, itching to be taken off by some cosmic socket wrench.  We may someday transcend into pure energyâ¦ because after all, matter is simply energy that is trapped.  I look forward to the day when my great great Grandchildren (or grandnephews, Iâm not counting that particular chicken until sheâs in my bed) will shake off these obsolete earthly bindings, and float seamlessly into the Aether.  Maybe it will happen within my lifetime.  Innovation is happening more and more quicklyâ¦ Following the Ideas up to the present, Agriculture to Smithing, to Industry, to computers, to god knows whatâs been invented this weekâ¦ thereâs exponentially less time between leaps, and the distance each leap covers is growing exponentially the other way.  So in time, there will be a critical juncture, as these equations we call life reach their asymptotes, and everything will start happening very quickly.  So donât get caught with your pants down.  To quote an enlightened being who was trying to eliminate all the needless law and rhetoric (again, another post altogether), âRepent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand,â or somesuchâ¦ all I know is, itâs going to be a hell of a ride.  Our childhoods are lengthening because we need to have the limber minds of the young in order to transcend.  All this advancement, all this history, all these conversations could be preparing us for something amazing.  Maybe we need to cast off the tools and speeches and knowledge that has brought us this far, like booster rockets falling off of a space shuttle, hurtling towards the inky depths of space, expanding infinitely, and becoming what we were meant to be.   whether we like it or not, whether we KNOW about it or notâ¦  we are, all of us, constantly becoming.  Hereâs to 24.      --The Slater

One Year for Every Hour: Birthday Reflections    So it comes to this - birthday comes and strips away a year of youthâ¦ slaps on a shiny new coat of old.
